EGD could be the first registered to the ISO 14001 Standard

by Tony Kirby

If you've ever travelled on an ocean liner when a stabilizer has malfunctioned you'll appreciate the value of this vessel feature.

Stabilizers are located on cruise ships at mid-hull, below the water line, and are extended to provide additional stability and reduce the rolling motion of ships during voryage. They are hydro-dynamically designed and require regular maintenance and occasional repair.

While crossing the Atlantic some years ago, aboard the Holland-America Line's Maasdam, something went wrong with one of the stabilizers - in quiet seas, and the ship suddenly tipped over to one side. I was lucky to get away without bruises but one or two passengers suffered broken bones.

'Stabilizer pockets' - recesses built into the concrete walls of a graving dock to enable cruise ships to extend their stabilizers for inspections, maintenance and repairs while in dry dock - are now a feature of the Esquimalt Graving Dock (EGD) in Victoria, BC.

The dock is a public facility operated by Public Works & Government Services Canada, and is the largest non-military graving dock on the west coast of the Americas. Victoria's mild climate makes the location ideal for shipbuilding, repair and maintenance work. There is also an abundant supply of skilled labour.

Staffed by 42 full-time federal employees, the actual work on the vessels that use the graving dock is contracted out to private companies, including work on federal and provincial government vessels. The staff operate the dock on a 24-hour, 365-day a year basis, supplying crane services, dock services, and air, power and water.

"We are literally an around-the-clock facility," says acting manager Bob desmarais. "We even kept going during the severe snowstorm of '96. We have been really busy for the last six years, and currently have bookings up to 2005, mostly with ferries, but also with ocean liners, offshore fishing vessels, and government vessels."

The graving dock was originally designed to accommodate the largest capital ships of the Royal Navy during the days when the British Empire covered much of the globe. Over its 70-year history, the facility has handled everything from steam-powered vessels to the largest of today's conventional ships.

During World War 2 the dock was used for the refitting and conversion of the ocean-going liners to troopships, the most famous of which was the Queen Elizabeth. Today, the facility is capable of accomaditng and servicing more than 90 per-cent of all foreign and domestic vessels operating on the west coast.

The dock is a popular location for repair and refit work for vessels engaged in the west coast cruise ship trade, for bulk and general cargo vessels plying the Pacific Rim, and for elements of the domestic fleet - especially the Royal Canadian Navy and the BC Ferry Corporation.


Infinity

Sun Princess

What size vessel can the graving dock handle?

"Victoria Shipyards recently worked on the 960-ft. long ocean liner Infinity here, a vessel which required maintenance to its Mermaid propulsion units," says Bob.

Over the past 10 years, the graving dock has experienced considerable expansion and modernization, including the construction of new 150 tonne and 30 tonne level luffing cranes, refurbishing of the dock's electrical and pumping infrastructure, and enclosing the dock on the south wharf.


EGD's 150-tonne crane

The latest addition, the stabilizer pockets, were used for the first time by Victoria Shipyards and September of last year with the arrival of the Sun Princess of Princess Cruise Lines.

"We are extremely pleased with the addition of stabilizer pockets at the Esquimalt Graving Dock," says Malcolm Barker, Manager of Operation for Victoria Shipyards. "It will help the shipbuilding industry attract new business as well as add value to our existing business."

Esquimalt Graving Dock has been certified by Lloyds of London as being in compliance with the United States Military Standard 1625B (SH). It is now expected to achieve another important certification this September, the ISO 14001 Environmental Management System certificaiton.

ISO 14001 certification

Environmental responsibility has become a priority at the Esquimalt Graving Dock. The EGD has implemented an environmental Management System (EMS) based upon ISO 14001, the international standard for environmental management. The EGD is currently undergoing the audit process to become registered to the standard.

"I believe that we would be the first large industrial shipyard in North America to become registered to the ISO 14001 Standard," says Daryl Lawes, EGD's Environmental coordinator. "Our program is generating interest from shipyards on the east coast, as well as the industry in Washington State and Norfolk, Virginia."


Spill training course

The ISO Standard has provided the framework for the EGD to develop a management system to manage the environmental aspects of its operations. The EGD has worked closely with a number of ship repair firms to develop the system, including Victoria Shipyards, Esquimalt Drydock Company, Jenkins Marine, and Point Hope Shipyards, as well as clients such as BC Ferries and the Canadian Navy.

"From the very first stages of developing the system, we knew its success depended on the participation of the ship repair firms and ship owners," says Daryl. "We have taken a cooperative approach and achieved the supportand buy-in of all the users."

Here are some of the benefits of implementing the standard:

  • Increased Competitiveness. Many companies, particularly cruise lines and government fleets, want to be sure that the operations associated with their business are done in an environmentally responsible manner. Having their ships worked on in a facility with an ISO 14001 management system provides a level of confidence.
  • Environmetnal Protection. The system requires commitments and procedures for environmetnal protection, pollution prevention, and continual improvement.
  • Compliance Assuratnce. The system requires commitments to compliance with applicable regulations and regularly measures this compliance.
  • Waste Reduction. Cost savings are realized through the tracking and reduction of wastes generated.

Key environmental iniatives at EGD


  • EGD's air quality monitoring program
    Development of Best Management Practices Manual. Through a series of workshops and meetings, a set of guidelines was developed to ensure that operations at the EGD were conducted in an environmentally responsible manner.
  • Air Quality / Noise Monitoring Programs. the EGD has implemented noise monitoring and particulate monitoring programs to ensure that activities commonly associated with ship maintenance and repair - such as sandblasting - are managed so as to mitigate any off-site impacts.
  • Environmental Awareness / Training Programs. An extensive training program has been developed so that employees and ship repair contractors are aware of their responsibilities for protecting the environment.
  • Environmental Blasting Equipment. The GED is promoting the use of advanced vacuum abrasive blasting equipment, which reduces the amount of particulate generated by 99 per-cent over conventional surface preparation methods and greatly reduces the amount of waste generated.
  • Stormwater Monitoring Program. Discharges from the dry dock and work areas are regularly monitored for pollutants.

Facts and figures on Esquimalt Graving Dock

The graving dock, with dimensions of 357 metres by 38.4 metres, is divisible into two sections through the insertion of an intermediate caisson gate. It is a monolithic concrete structure with granite blocks used the cope, quoins and three levels of the altars.

Closure of the dock is by floating caissons ballasted with concrete and sea water. Watering and de-watering is through a main tunnel on the north isde.

This tunnel connects to separate tunnels which enables each dock section to fill independently through culverts on the floor.

The north landing jetty is 305 metres long and contains 10 metres of water depth at low tide. There is another 406 metres of berth frontage at the south landing wharf. In addition, there is ample open space available for fabrication and component assembly activities, if required.


Source: Resource People, September 2001
